Improved Wong and classical approximations, and reduction of fusion data

L.F. Canto canto@if.ufrj.br Instituto de F√≠sica, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, CP 68528, 21941-972, Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ V. A. B. Zagatto vzagatto@id.uff.br Instituto de F√≠sica, Universidade Federal Fluminense, Av. Litoranea s/n, Gragoat√°, Niter√≥i, R.J., 24210-340, Brazil ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ J. Lubian jlubian@id.uff.br Instituto de F√≠sica, Universidade Federal Fluminense, Av. Litoranea s/n, Gragoat√°, Niter√≥i, R.J., 24210-340, Brazil ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ R. Donangelo donangel@fing.edu.uy Instituto de F√≠sica, Facultad de Ingenier√≠a, Universidad de la Rep√∫blica, Av. Julio Herrera y Reissig 565, 11300 Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract

We present an improved version of the Wong formula for heavy-ion fusion, where the parameters of the parabolic approximation of the Coulomb barrier are replaced by parameters of the lùëôlitalic_l-dependent potential at an effective partial-wave. A pocket formula for this lùëôlitalic_l-dependence is given. This version reproduces the fusion cross sections of quantum mechanical calculations very well, even when the original Wong formula is not valid. The same procedure is used to derive an improved expression for the classical fusion cross section, which is very accurate at above-barrier energies. Based on this classical expression, we propose a new method to reduce fusion data in this energy range. This method is used to perform a comparative study of complete fusion suppression in collisions of weakly bound projectiles. This study indicates that the suppression of complete fusion is essentially due to the action of nuclear breakup couplings.

‚Ä†‚Ä†preprint: APS/123-QED

I Introduction

The dynamics of fusion reactions are highly complex, especially in collisions of projectiles with low breakup thresholds (lower than 3 or 4 MeV)¬†Canto et¬†al. (2006); Keeley et¬†al. (2007, 2009); Canto et¬†al. (2015a); Kolata et¬†al. (2016); Canto et¬†al. (2020). Owing to the low binding energy, the projectile can break up as it approaches the target, giving rise to different fusion processes. First, is the direct complete fusion (DCF), where the whole projectile fuses with the target. This is the usual fusion reaction, observed also in the collisions of tightly bound nuclei. In addition, the breakup of the projectile triggers two more fusion processes: the incomplete fusion (ICF) and the sequential complete fusion (SCF). The former occurs when at least one, but not all, projectile fragments fuse with the target. The latter takes place when all breakup fragments fuse sequentially with the target. Experimentally, SCF cannot be distinguished from DCF. The experimental cross section corresponds to complete fusion (CF), the sum DCF + SCF. Besides, many experiments cannot distinguish CF from ICF. Then, the data correspond to total fusion (TF), the sum of all fusion processes.

In collisions of weakly bound projectiles, the low breakup threshold affects the CF cross section in two ways. Owing to the low binding energy, the projectile‚Äôs density has a long tail, leading to a reduction of the Coulomb barrier. This is a static effect, which enhances CF at all collision energies. On the other hand, the low breakup threshold leads to strong breakup couplings, diverting an appreciable part of the incident flux into the breakup channel. This is a dynamic effect that hinders CF. In this way, the CF data is the net result of the competition between the opposing static and dynamic effects of the low binding energy of the projectile. Experimental and theoretical studies indicate that the CF cross section is enhanced at sub-barrier energies and suppressed above the Coulomb barrier¬†Canto et¬†al. (2006); Keeley et¬†al. (2007, 2009); Canto et¬†al. (2015a); Kolata et¬†al. (2016); Canto et¬†al. (2020). However, the present understanding of CF reactions is not entirely satisfactory. New experimental and theoretical studies are called for.

There are different methods to assess the influence of the low breakup threshold of the projectile on the CF cross section. The first is to compare the CF data to predictions of theoretical models that do not consider the projectile‚Äôs low binding. A standard procedure is to compare them to fusion cross sections of one-channel calculations with a standard real potential and short-range absorption. Usually, one adopts implementations of the double-folding model with standard nuclear densities, like the S√£o Paulo (SPP)¬†Chamon et¬†al. (1997, 2002) or the Aky√ºz-Winther (AW)¬†Aky√ºz and Winther (1981) potential. A more straightforward approach is to compare the data to predictions of semiclassical or classical approximations to the quantum mechanical (QM) treatment, like the barrier penetration model (BPM), the Wong formula¬†Wong (1973), or even the classical fusion cross section. However, one should ensure that the approximate model for the theoretical cross section is valid under the conditions of the experiment. Then, the differences between the experimental and the theoretical cross sections are assumed to arrive from the low binding energy of the projectile.

The other possibility is to compare CF data of the weakly bound system to fusion data of similar tightly bound systems. However, direct comparisons of the data would be meaningless since they are strongly dependent on the charges and masses of the collision partners. Thus, submitting the data to some reduction procedure that eliminates the influence of such trivial factors is necessary. Several reduction procedures have been proposed (for a review, see Canto et¬†al. (2015b)). A very efficient one is the fusion function (FF) reduction method, which is based on the Wong formula¬†Wong (1973). In an ideal situation where the fusion cross section is unaffected by the collision partners‚Äô intrinsic structure, and the Wong formula approximates the QM cross section, the reduced data is well described by a universal fusion function. Then, this universal function is used as a benchmark to assess the importance of channel coupling effects in the fusion data. However, the Wong formula is not a good approximation to the QM cross section for light systems at sub-barrier energies and at energies well above the barrier¬†Canto et¬†al. (2009a, b, c).

In the present paper, we discuss the limitations of the Wong formula and the classical expression for the fusion cross section. We show that their validity can be extended if one replaces the s-wave barrier parameters with effective barrier parameters obtained by proper angular-momentum averages. Then, we propose a new reduction method for the above-barrier fusion data based on this improved version of the classical cross section. This method is used to study CF data of weakly bound systems.

The paper is organized as follows. In Sec.¬†II, we discuss the use of complex interactions in potential scattering to simulate the effects of fusion and total reaction in the scattering wave function. In sec.¬†III, we introduce the classical and Wong approximations to the QM fusion cross section. We then discuss the validity of these approximations and the classical limit of the Wong formula. In Sec.¬†IV, we develop new versions of Wong and the classical approximations and then propose a new reduction method based on the latter. In Sec.¬†V, we use the new reduction method to perform a comparative study of CF data in collisions of 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi, 77{}^{7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi, 99{}^{9}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBe, and 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe on several targets. Finally, in Sec.¬†VI, we give the main conclusions of the present paper.

II The fusion and the reaction cross sections in potential scattering

In an idealized situation where the intrinsic degrees of freedom of the collision partners do not affect the collision, the elastic cross section can be described by potential scattering. In this approach, the colliding nuclei are treated as point particles, interacting through Coulomb and nuclear forces. The scattering wave function is expanded in partial waves and the resulting radial wave functions are calculated by solving the radial equation with the lùëôlitalic_l-dependent potential

The attractive nuclear potential is very strong but has a short range. On the other hand, the repulsive Coulomb and centrifugal terms are weaker but have longer ranges. The competition between the attractive and repulsive terms leads to a barrier in the potential Vl‚Å¢(r)subscriptùëâùëôùëüV_{l}(r)italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ), located at RlsubscriptùëÖùëôR_{l}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and with height BlsubscriptùêµùëôB_{l}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

However, actual nucleus-nucleus collisions are always affected by intrinsic degrees of freedom, which are coupled with the coordinate rùëüritalic_r. Then, a fraction of the incident flux is diverted into nonelastic channels along the collision. In potential scattering, this effect is simulated by the addition of an attractive imaginary part to the nuclear potential, namely

The characteristics of the imaginary potential depend on the nuclear reactions whose effects it is simulating. This point is discussed below.

II.1 The total reaction cross section

The elastic cross section is influenced by fusion and nonelastic processes. The former only takes place when the densities of the collision partners overlap strongly. On the other hand, the latter are dominant in grazing collisions, where the distance of closest approach is larger than the barrier radius. Then, if one wants to evaluate the total reaction cross-section, which has contributions of both reaction mechanisms, the imaginary potential must be very strong in the inner region of the barrier but also act in the neighborhood of the barrier radius. Then, the range of W‚Å¢(r)ùëäùëüW(r)italic_W ( italic_r ) must be similar to that of the real part of the nuclear potential.

Frequently, the imaginary potential used in calculations of the total reaction cross section is represented by a Woods-Saxon (WS) function,

III The classical and the Wong approximations to the fusion cross section

The classical fusion cross section has a serious flaw: it vanishes at sub-barrier energies.

III.2 The Wong formula

C.Y. Wong¬†Wong (1973) derived an analytic expression for the fusion cross section, which includes tunneling effects. To get his formula, Wong made the same assumptions as in the derivation of the classical cross section, except for the transmission coefficient of Eq.¬†(24). Instead, he used the Hill-Wheeler transmission coefficient,

III.2.2 Validity of the Wong formula

The Wong formula is a very nice analytical expression, but its validity is limited. It is a very good approximation to the QM fusion cross-section in collisions of heavy systems (ZP‚Å¢ZT>500subscriptùëçPsubscriptùëçT500Z_{\rm P}Z_{\rm T}>500italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 500) at near-barrier energies¬†Canto et¬†al. (2009b). However, it is not appropriate for light systems or at collision energies well below or well above the barrier.

The accuracy of the Wong formula is illustrated in Fig.¬†3, which shows comparisons between œÉWsubscriptùúéW\sigma_{\rm W}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and œÉBPMsubscriptùúéBPM\sigma_{\rm BPM}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BPM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the 77{}^{7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi‚Äâ+‚Äâ 2727{}^{27}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 27 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAl (ZP‚Å¢ZT=39subscriptùëçPsubscriptùëçT39Z_{\rm P}Z_{\rm T}=39italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 39), 77{}^{7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi‚Äâ+‚Äâ209209{}^{209}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 209 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBi (ZP‚Å¢ZT=249subscriptùëçPsubscriptùëçT249Z_{\rm P}Z_{\rm T}=249italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 249), and 2424{}^{24}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 24 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTMg‚Äâ+‚Äâ138138{}^{138}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 138 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBa (ZP‚Å¢ZT=672subscriptùëçPsubscriptùëçT672Z_{\rm P}Z_{\rm T}=672italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 672) systems. For the two heavier systems, the Wong formula is quite close to œÉBPMsubscriptùúéBPM\sigma_{\rm BPM}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BPM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in this energy region. The situation is better for the other two heavier systems. For the 77{}^{7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi + 209209{}^{209}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 209 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBi and 2424{}^{24}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 24 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTMg‚Äâ+‚Äâ138138{}^{138}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 138 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBa systems at the same energy above VBsubscriptùëâBV_{\rm B}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, œÉWsubscriptùúéW\sigma_{\rm W}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exceeds œÉBPMsubscriptùúéBPM\sigma_{\rm BPM}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BPM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by 10% and ‚àº5%similar-toabsentpercent5\sim 5\%‚àº 5 %, respectively. The exceedingly large values of the Wong cross section above the Coulomb barrier can be traced back to neglecting the angular momentum dependence of the barrier parameters. A detailed discussion of the failure of the Wong formula is presented below.

At sub-barrier energies, the cross-section results exclusively from tunneling effects. Thus, it is susceptible to the shape of the potential barrier. Fig.¬†4 shows the Coulomb barriers and the parabolic fits for the three systems of Fig.¬†3. The potential axes are truncated at the lowest collision energies of our calculations, namely V‚Å¢(r)=VB‚àí4ùëâùëüsubscriptùëâB4V(r)=V_{\rm B}-4italic_V ( italic_r ) = italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 4¬†MeV. The comparison between the potential barrier of the 77{}^{7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi + 2727{}^{27}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 27 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAl system and the parabolic fit sheds light on the abnormally large values of the Wong cross-section at sub-barrier energies. The parabolic barrier is much thinner than the actual Coulomb barrier. Thus, the transmission coefficient for the parabola is unrealistically large. This leads to a considerable enhancement of œÉWsubscriptùúéW\sigma_{\rm W}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in comparison to œÉBPMsubscriptùúéBPM\sigma_{\rm BPM}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BPM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Conversely, the parabolic fits for the barriers of the two heavier systems are quite reasonable. Besides, the fitted barrier is thicker on the inner side of the barrier but thinner on the outer side. Then, there is some compensation in calculating the transmission factors, and the Wong formula reproduces the QM cross-sections well.

Now, we consider the Wong formula above the Coulomb barrier. In this case, the differences between œÉWsubscriptùúéW\sigma_{\rm W}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and œÉBPMsubscriptùúéBPM\sigma_{\rm BPM}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_BPM end_POSTSUBSCRIPT arise from the neglect of the angular momentum dependences of RŒªsubscriptùëÖùúÜR_{\lambda}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ‚Ñè‚Å¢œâŒªPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptùúîùúÜ\hbar\omega_{\lambda}roman_‚Ñè italic_œâ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, we have shown that the Wong cross-section reduces to the classical cross-section just above the Coulomb barrier, and this cross section does not depend on the barrier curvature. Then, we concentrate on the angular momentum dependence of RŒªsubscriptùëÖùúÜR_{\lambda}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

In the 77{}^{7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi + 2727{}^{27}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 27 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAl collision at E=36ùê∏36E=36italic_E = 36 MeV, the angular momentum dependence of RŒªsubscriptùëÖùúÜR_{\lambda}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Œª end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is significant. IV Improved versions of the Wong and the classical cross sections

The previous sub-section showed that the Wong formula works poorly for light systems at energies well below or above the Coulomb barrier. The problem can be fixed by introducing effective barrier parameters, R¬Ø¬ØùëÖ\overline{R}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_R end_ARG and ‚Ñè‚Å¢œâ¬ØPlanck-constant-over-2-pi¬Øùúî\hbar\bar{\omega}roman_‚Ñè over¬Ø start_ARG italic_œâ end_ARG, in the modified Wong formula,

IV.2 Reduction of fusion data and universal functions

A frequently used reduction procedure is the fusion function (FF) method, which is based on the Wong formula. The collision energy, Eùê∏Eitalic_E, and the fusion cross section, œÉFsubscriptùúéF\sigma_{\rm F}italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are transformed into the dimensionless quantities

E‚Üíx=E‚àíVB‚Ñè‚Å¢œâ,œÉF‚ÜíF‚Å¢(x)=œÉFœÉ0,formulae-sequence‚Üíùê∏ùë•ùê∏subscriptùëâBPlanck-constant-over-2-piùúî‚ÜísubscriptùúéFùêπùë•subscriptùúéFsubscriptùúé0E\,\rightarrow\,x=\frac{E-V_{\rm B}}{\hbar\omega},\qquad\sigma_{\rm F}\,% \rightarrow\,F(x)=\frac{\sigma_{\rm F}}{\sigma_{0}},italic_E ‚Üí italic_x = divide start_ARG italic_E - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_‚Ñè italic_œâ end_ARG , italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ‚Üí italic_F ( italic_x ) = divide start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , (55)

As a simple test, the reduction procedures can be applied to the BPM fusion cross section¬†Canto et¬†al. (2009b, 2015b). The procedure is successful if reduced cross sections for systems in different mass ranges are very similar. Further, if the procedure leads to a universal function, the reduced cross-sections should be very close to it. We applied this test to the two versions of the fusion function method, Eqs.¬†(55) and (56).

V Application: reduced cross sections of weakly bound systems

The experimental fusion functions evaluated by the IFF method are very similar to the ones reduced by the standard FF method, reported in Ref.¬†Canto et¬†al. (2009a). The advantage of the former over the latter method is that it does not require a renormalization to take care of the inaccuracies of the Wong formula. However, the results of the two methods are very similar. For this reason, the discussion of the present section will be focused on the CFF reduction method.

We used the CFF method to reduce the fusion data of several tightly and weakly bound systems, performing the transformations

E‚ü∂y=1‚àíVBE,G¬Øexp‚Å¢(y)=œÉFexpœÄ‚Å¢R¬Ø2.formulae-sequence‚ü∂ùê∏ùë¶1subscriptùëâBùê∏superscript¬Øùê∫expùë¶superscriptsubscriptùúéFexpùúãsuperscript¬ØùëÖ2E\ \longrightarrow\ y=1-\frac{V_{\rm B}}{E},\qquad\ \overline{G}^{\,\rm exp}(y% )=\frac{\sigma_{\,\rm F}^{\rm exp}}{\pi\,\overline{R}^{2}}.italic_E ‚ü∂ italic_y = 1 - divide start_ARG italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_E end_ARG , over¬Ø start_ARG italic_G end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_y ) = divide start_ARG italic_œÉ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_œÄ over¬Ø start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG . (62)

To accomplish this goal, one needs the barrier height of the potential, VBsubscriptùëâBV_{\rm B}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the effective barrier radius, R¬Ø¬ØùëÖ\overline{R}over¬Ø start_ARG italic_R end_ARG.

V.1 Comparative study of experimental CFFs

In this section, we apply the CFF reduction method to the fusion data of weakly bound systems.

Before considering weakly bound systems, we submitted the CFF method to a test similar to the one carried out in Sect.¬†IV.2. The difference is that instead of applying it to BPM cross sections, we reduce experimental fusion cross sections of tightly bound systems where nuclear structure properties do not influence the cross section at above-barrier energies. In such cases, one expects the reduced fusion data to be very close to the classical fusion line of Eq.¬†(59).

Fig.¬†9 shows the experimental CFF for the 44{}^{4}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe + 209209{}^{209}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 209 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBi¬†Hassan et¬†al. Now, we study CFFs associated with the CF of weakly bound projectiles. As we will show below, the reduced data of these systems can be fitted by a linear function through the origin of the form

This probability is usually called the suppression factor. We do not adopt this terminology here, because it is not intuitive: a large suppression factor corresponds, actually, to a small suppression, and the other way around.

Œ±Li7=0.70.superscriptùõºsuperscriptLi70.70\alpha^{{}^{7}{\rm Li}}=0.70.italic_Œ± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT roman_Li end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.70 . (65)

Comparing Figs.¬†10(a) and 10(b), one observes that the CF survival factor decreases with the breakup threshold of the projectile, as expected. However, these figures reveal another very interesting behavior of the CF suppression: it seems independent of the target charge. The results for 9090{}^{90}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 90 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTZr (ZT=40subscriptùëçT40Z_{\rm T}=40italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 40) are essentially the same as the ones for the 209209{}^{209}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 209 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBi target (ZT=83subscriptùëçT83Z_{\rm T}=83italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 83), which has an atomic number about twice as large. Note that the same conclusion was reached in the study of Kumawat et al.¬†Kumawat et¬†al. (2012). This finding suggests that the Coulomb breakup does not affect the CF cross section. Thus, one is led to the conclusion that the observed CF suppression in collisions of weakly bound projectiles with heavy targets is due to nuclear breakup. This conclusion seems to contradict our knowledge of breakup reactions, which are strongly influenced by Coulomb breakup and Coulomb-nuclear interference¬†Nunes and Thompson (1998, 1999); Otomar et¬†al. (2013); Descouvemont et¬†al. (2017).

However, there is a significant difference between the breakup and the fusion processes. The former gets contributions from hundreds of partial waves, most corresponding to distant collisions, where the distance of closest approach is larger than the range of the nuclear potential. At lower partial waves, nuclear couplings are also relevant, and there are strong Coulomb-nuclear interference effects. Nuclear couplings dominate only at the lowest partial waves. However, their contributions are small due to the factor (2‚Å¢l+1)2ùëô1(2l+1)( 2 italic_l + 1 ) contained in the partial-wave expansion of the breakup cross section.

The fusion process is quite different. At high angular momenta, the centrifugal barrier prevents the system from reaching the strong absorption region, where the fusion processes occur. Thus, it is unsurprising that Coulomb couplings play a major role in the breakup process, but they have a negligible influence on the CF cross section. Then, only l‚â≤lgless-than-or-similar-toùëôsubscriptùëôgl\lesssim l_{\rm g}italic_l ‚â≤ italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contributes to fusion, and the nuclear couplings are dominant at these angular momenta.

Now, we discuss the collisions of 99{}^{9}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBe projectiles. They are also very interesting since their breakup threshold is only 1.65 MeV. There are available CF data for collisions of 99{}^{9}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBe with several targets: 144144{}^{144}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 144 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTSm¬†Gomes et¬†al. (2009b), 197197{}^{197}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 197 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAu¬†Li et¬†al. (2019); Kaushik et¬†al. (2020); Gollan et¬†al. A comparative study of the CF data of these systems, reduced by the fusion function method, was presented in Fig.¬†13 of Ref.¬†Gollan et¬†al. (2021). This comparison was inconclusive since the data did not show any trend. The CF survival factors for systems in the same mass range differed considerably. However, we emphasize that the data for different targets were measured by different groups using different experimental techniques. Thus, a detailed study of the experimental procedures of each experiment would be needed before one can draw reliable conclusions and this would be beyond the scope of the present work. Nevertheless, the data for the 99{}^{9}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBe + 208208{}^{208}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 208 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPb and the 6,767{}^{6,7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 , 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi + 209209{}^{209}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 209 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBi systems, analyzed in the previous two figures, were measured by the same group using similar experimental techniques. Then, we restrict our study to 99{}^{9}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBe + 208208{}^{208}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 208 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPb.

The experimental CFF for the 99{}^{9}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 9 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBe + 208208{}^{208}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 208 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTPb system is shown in Fig.¬†10(c), in comparison to the classical fusion line. One finds that the reduced data points are also distributed along the linear function of Eq.¬†(63), but now the CF survival factor is

Since the breakup threshold of this nucleus lies between the ones of the two Li isotopes, this result is consistent with the assumption that the CF survival factor decreases with the breakup threshold of the projectile.

Finally, we look at collisions of the two-neutron halo nucleus 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe. Since experiments involving unstable beams are much more challenging, fusion data involving 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe projectiles are very scarce. Nevertheless, there are good CF data for the 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe + 209209{}^{209}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 209 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBi system at several collision energies and the 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe + 238238{}^{238}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 238 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTU system at a few collision energies. In typical situations, CF followed by the evaporation of two neutrons cannot be distinguished from ICF events with the capture of the 44{}^{4}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe cluster. However, the CF cross sections could be measured under special conditions of these experiments. Kolata et al.¬†Kolata et¬†al. (1998a, b) measured the CF cross section for the 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi + 209209{}^{209}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 209 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBi system at near-barrier energies. The CF of this system leads to the formation of the 215215{}^{215}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 215 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAt, which evaporates 1, 2, 3, and 4 neutrons. The cross section was determined by measuring the characteristic alpha particles emitted by the 212212{}^{212}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 212 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAt and 211211{}^{211}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 211 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAt residual nuclei, which, according to statistical model code predictions¬†¬†Kolata et¬†al. (1998a, b), are the dominant decay modes within the energy interval of the experiment. The 212212{}^{212}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 212 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAt and 211211{}^{211}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 211 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTAt are also formed by the breakup of the projectile, followed by the capture of the 44{}^{4}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe cluster (ICFŒ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ±). However, owing to excitation energy considerations¬†Ferreira et¬†al. (2023), these nuclei could not emit the alpha particles detected in the experiment. Nevertheless, they are expected to make a small contribution to the data points at the highest collision energies.

The CF cross section for the 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe + 238238{}^{238}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 238 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTU system was measured by Raabe et al.¬†Raabe et¬†al. (2004). In this case, the signature of CF events was the detection of two fission fragments emitted back to back, unaccompanied by a third charged fragment with a projectile-like kinematic. In fact, the same residual nucleus can be formed by the CF and the ICFŒ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± processes after the evaporation of different numbers of neutrons (two more neutrons in the case of CF). However, comparing the fission barrier with the excitation energies in the CF and ICFŒ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± processes, one concludes that the latter does not contribute to the measured cross section¬†Ferreira et¬†al. (2023).

Fig.¬†10(d) shows the experimental CFFs corresponding to the CF data of the 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe + 209209{}^{209}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 209 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTBi and 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTHe + 238238{}^{238}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 238 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTU systems. One observes that the results exhibit the same behavior as the CFFs for 77{}^{7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi projectiles. The data points of both systems are very close to the black dotted line, which corresponds to the function of Eq.¬†(65). Note that the experimental CFF tends to grow above the dotted line at the two data points with the highest energies. This is likely due to spurious contributions from ICFŒ±ùõº\alphaitalic_Œ± events, which, according to PACE estimates, become relevant at the highest energies of the experiment.

In the calculation of the CFFs of Figs.¬†10(a), 10(b), 10(c), and 10(d), we used the radii of the Coulomb barriers of the SPP and the approximate expression for fR‚Å¢(y)subscriptùëìRùë¶f_{\rm R}(y)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y ) (Eq.¬†54). The barrier parameters of the SPP for the weakly bound systems studied in the present work are listed in Table¬†3.

VI Conclusions

We derived an improved version of the Wong formula for heavy-ion fusion that is valid under conditions where the standard Wong formula is inaccurate. This is achieved by replacing the s-wave barrier parameters in the Wong formula with the parameters of the lùëôlitalic_l-dependent potential barrier at an effective partial wave, given by an average over angular momentum. The same procedure is used to obtain an improved expression for the classical fusion cross section.

The improved Wong cross sections for systems over a broad mass range were compared to the corresponding cross sections of the barrier penetration model. They were shown to be in excellent agreement. An analogous comparison was made for the improved classical fusion cross sections of the same systems. In this case, it was restricted to energies above the Coulomb barrier. The agreement with the barrier penetration model cross section was also extremely good.

Based on the improved classical cross sections, we proposed a new procedure to reduce the fusion data of different systems. This procedure, which we called the classical fusion function method, leads to a new universal function, the classical fusion line, which plays the role of a benchmark in comparisons of reduced fusion data. This method was used to study the suppression of complete fusion in collisions of weakly bound projectiles. Comparisons of reduced cross sections in collisions of 66{}^{6}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi and 77{}^{7}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPTLi with targets over a wide mass range lead to two conclusions: (i) The suppression increases as the breakup threshold of the projectile increases, (ii) the suppression does not seem to depend on the target charge. This indicates that the suppression of complete fusion is mainly due to nuclear breakup couplings.
